It's still dumb and annoying. I will give it credit for making funny references to the books. It was also shot better than the other movies (another surprise). I guess you know what's coming since it's from the same guys who made Disaster Movie and Epic Movie. I really don't recommend this movie. I guess you can see it if you REALLY hate Twilight, or if you're a twilight fan who likes to see it made fun of. But it's still nothing special.

3.5/10

review_title: People clearly didn't get the point
review_detailed_main: Reading the reviews is amazing to see how many of this people clearly missed the point. Of course the movie is completely ridiculous, that's the point! Parodies exists to make fun of the original material, and that it definitely did

After making the woefully regrettable decision to pay money to see "Epic Movie", I had vowed to stay far away from this movie and any other with the word "Movie" in the title. But, because I am faint of heart and/or an idiot, I allowed myself to be talked into watching a leaked version online because A) it was actually pretty funny, according to friends who had seen it already, B) it was only about 70 minutes long, and C) this Edward was actually hot. After watching it for myself, I would agree on all three counts (especially C.daaaaamn). It's no great cinematic achievement, but for a devoted Twilight hater such as myself, it was worth a chuckle or two.

Sure, "Vampires Suck" meets many of the same pitfalls other parody movies do. It operates under the delusion that anyone out of diapers thinks that a character being bludgeoned over the head time and time again for absolutely no reason is comedy gold. It often relies on stupid pop culture jokes (Look! A Jersey Shore reference! It's funny because it is a Jersey shore reference!) and unoriginal gross-out humor (it's funny because you want to vomit! Haha!). But, so help me if I didn't find myself laughing at the way the film mercilessly mocks everything laughable about the Twilight movies, a series that, let's face it, lends itself pretty easily to parody. In fact, all "Vampires Suck" really had to do was recreate the first two Twilight films pretty much scene-for-scene, tweaking here and there to make the scenes only slightly more ridiculous than the originals. The result is actually a pretty clever send-up of the ludicrously over-the-top melodrama that Twilight lovers eat up. This film holds a mirror up to pretty much everything laughable about the series that proves that a wildly successful book/movie franchise does not necessarily need a "plot": the rabidity of its fan base; the shameless parade of shirtless males; the idea that teenage Stephanie Meyerer, I mean, Bella, would be the object of every hot guy's lust despite being a mopy sourpuss with no trace of a personality; the insistence that Robert Pattinson is "sexy". The actress who plays Bella, or "Becca," as she is renamed, does a killer job parodying Kristen Stewart's mannerisms (hair-tucking, downward gazes, constant lower-lip biting) by which I mean she mimics them exactly and everyone laughs at them because they are stupid. Mocking Twilight is not exactly hard to do, but I have to say this film does it quite cleverly at many points. I'll even say that the ending is magnificent.

Needless to say, "Vampires Suck" is for members of Team I Want a Boy Who Doesn't Want to Kill Me only, as I'm sure Twilight fans would not appreciate being forced to acknowledge that the thing they love is dumber than a sack of fruit fly larvae. However, since like I said the movie is pretty much just a re-creation of the original Twilight movies, many of the jokes are best appreciated having actually seen them. So you'll probably like this movie if you are not a Twilight fan, but have actually seen the movies because A) you were dragged there by a girl whose pants you really, REALLY wanted to get into, B) you were stoned, walked into the wrong theater, and failed to realize that it wasn't The Hangover until it was too late, or C) you are self-loathing and willingly subjected yourself to them out of morbid curiosity (like me).

So if you hate Twilight and everything it stands for, take a break from your violent (yet strangely erotic) fantasies about Robert Pattinson and Taylor Lautner and go see "Vampires Suck". It will ease your tortured soul, and maybe, just maybe, restore a molecule of faith in the parody genre. It couldn't possibly be worse than "Meet the Spartans".

review_title: Shoots at Big, Fat Target; Could Have Been SO Much Worse
review_detailed_main:
Vampires Suck (1:22, PG-13) — other: comedy; bargain basement; formula

The writing-directing team of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, along with producer Peter Safran, are the 3 in the Box production company. Considering that their previous movie was the monumentally dreadful Disaster Movie, and considering how bad this satire of vampire romances could have been, it didn't suck all that badly. Which is not to say that I recommend it, of course, but you needn't bring a barf bag with you.

The F-S team is also responsible for such other spoof films as Meet the Spartans, Epic Movie, Date Movie, and the later, lesser installments in the Scary Movie series. This time around, they abandon the kitchen-sink approach and choose to satirize only 1 of the many available vampiric targets, the Twilight series based on the novels by Stephenie Meyer. No mention at all of Dracula, Nosferatu, Saint Germain, Lestat, or Bill Nighy's clan from the Underworld series. The sole exception is a super-brief cameo by Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

In general, this was a wise choice, as there is soooooo much worth satirizing in Twilight (including its devoted fans, known among themselves as Twilighters and among the less enraptured as Twihards*) that it provides ample source material. Bringing in material from other canons would only have garbled the main story line.

And that story line is a fairly faithful retelling of the Twilight saga to date, except done as high camp. (Make that highER camp.)

Jenn Proske as Becca Crane does a dead-to-rights impression of Kristen Stewart as Bella Swan. She's got all the tics and mannerisms down cold. She's always clutching her sweater's overlong sleeves, smoothing her hair behind her ear, dropping her eyes as she talks to people, biting her lower lip, and generally moping and mooning about. Matt Lanter as Edward Sullen does a pretty good Robert Pattinson as Edward Cullen, and Chris Riggi as Jacob White is a spot-on Taylor Lautner as Jacob Black. Really, while this is a low-budget production, and all of the leads were unknowns, the casting was top-flight. The make-up was pretty good, too, altho I think it would have been even better satire to go with mime-style whiteface and blood-red lipstick 100% of the time, instead of as fitfully as they did. Special mention for Edward's hair (including the curler scene), which deserves the cover of Architecture Today.

The humor emanates mainly from breaking the 4th wall with self-referential allusions to the movie-making process, as when Jacob, asked why he's always taking off his shirt, promptly hauls out his acting contract. Other bits rely on incongruity, such as the unexpected appearance of the Segway. There's just plain foolishness, such as Edward demonstrating his dexterity by juggling an apple, a bowling ball, and a baby. And there's gross exaggeration, such as the world's worst paper cut. Blessedly, there are almost no bodily-function gags (well, aside from the bloodsucking, of course), save for one semi-justifiable fart joke.

But mainly it's a straight-up satire of the original. It hits maybe half the time, and the other half of the time, when it's missing, it's mainly because the original was already such a satire of itself that it's almost impossible to overdo it.

Good effort and worth it for Twilight completists, tho the True Believers will probably think it blasphemous.

––––––––

*For the record, I rated the 3 actual Twilight movies 7-5-7 on my 9-point scale, which makes me mildly appreciative but hardly a devotee.

review_title: A Definite no-go for all the movie lovers

review_detailed_main:
Well, I am not a "Twilight" fan, but I am a fan of spoof movies that suck (no pun intended) on the fame of other movies. And "Vampires Suck" did just that, literally.

I was cool to see how they re-told the "Twilight" saga with a handful of laughs, stupid jokes, silly events and embarrassing moments and dialogue. "Vampires Suck" does stand out from other spoofs such as "Scary Movie", "Epic Movie", "Superhero Movie" and the like, as it doesn't steal and borrow stuff from multiple sources. It just sticks to the overrated "Twilight" saga.

Now, the movie in itself was long to sit through, especially because it wasn't funny all the time. In fact, there were long between laughs. But when the laughs were there, they were well earned. One thing that really was amazing was how they had managed to replicate and make the movie seem like the "Twilight" movies. The sets were fantastic and very believable. I guess even the 'true' hardcore "Twilight" fans (or young teen girls, as they truly are) would even agree with me on that one.

There was a lot of really stupid comedy in the movie, but many of the scenes actually did work out quite well. And also nice to people like David DeLuise and Ken Jeong in a movie like this.

The low rating for the movie is because there were surprisingly few laughs in the movie, and it was a bit too long to sit through. It lacked the comedy pull to make it worthwhile. But the sets, settings and whole believability of it all managed to save it from sinking even lower on the ranking scale.

Without giving anything away, the ending was the best part of the movie. That was freaking hilarious. That was, without a doubt, the best scene throughout the entire movie.

This was far more interesting than original franchise and it really mocked everything about Twilight. The lead actress is more likeable than Kristen Stewart. It's dumb, and stupid but that's how a parody should be.

review_title: Maybe I've just gotten used to them, maybe they've actually gotten better. . .
review_detailed_main:
Oh, Friedberg and Seltzer. How woefully you are viewed upon by over half the film world's population today. The films you have made have been deemed some of the worst ever. However, there are still some traces of fans out there, whether anyone believes it or not. I, myself, am certainly not a fan, but I understand both sides of the scale and review your films unbiasedly. With that said, I have to admit that I rather enjoyed the latest spoof from these two.

The Twilight phenomenon is an utter joke among many already. A feature length spoof of the movies seemed like it was bound to happen, but who would have known it would have been created by them. Some might enjoy this because they find any mocking of the Twlight films joyous. Some might enjoy this because they honestly find the antics humorous. Most will hate it entirely because of the directors. In any matter, I found it fun because of how well crafted I actually thought it was and how many times it made me laugh because of how funny the movie managed to be by working off the films' it mocks cheesiness areas.

Like some have already reviewed saying, this is an improvement in many ways. Unlike all their other films, this actually focuses on spoofing just the two first Twilight films and does not rely on criticizing every film they possibly can as well as making lame pop culture reference after lame pop culture reference to get giggles, even though there still are pop culture references in there, they're just not as lame and are spaced out for our brain's convenience.

Jenn Proske and Matt Lanter are actually incredible, in a sense, in their performances. Proske covered every Kristen Stewart fault swimmingly as did Matt Lanter for Robert Pattinson. Even though that's generally not something to be proud of, it works here. The movie doesn't linger on humorless side jokes until the point where boredom is spewing out of our mouths, and the crew captures the essence that I was looking for in this film. Yes, it has many problems, what Friedberg and Seltzer film doesn't? It still is entertaining in the right mood, and just maybe the two have finally started to perfect on what they have been oblivious to all this time, or maybe I have just gotten used to their mediocrity, but regardless, I think this film deserves more appreciation than some Friedberg and Seltzer haters will give it.

review_title: Worse than the franchise its parodying
review_detailed_main:
Twilight was one of the most annoying franchises of the last decade, and certainly ripe for parody. Unfortunately, most of its parodies are shallow "comedies" that reference certain scenes, and then insert flatulence jokes and uninspired slapstick in them. That's Vampires Suck (2010) in a nutshell.

Random is the word of the day here. Random musical numbers, random celebrities popping up out of nowhere, random fights, random references to other bits of popular culture that have nothing to do with Twilight or vampires. I understand most people think random equals funny, but guess what? It doesn't. It just makes for a boring, frustrating mess of a movie.

review_title: This summer, Twilight get's funny!! Or so it seems..?!
Not a hit but not a bust

review_detailed_main:
'VAMPIRES SUCK': A Half a Star (Out of Five)

Another spoof movie from writers / directors Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, this one parodies 'THE TWILIGHT SAGA' (specifically the first two films). Friedberg and Seltzer are the same team responsible for such notoriously bad slapstick as 'DATE MOVIE', 'EPIC MOVIE', 'MEET THE SPARTANS', 'DISASTER MOVIE' and they also co-wrote 'SPY HARD' and the original 'SCARY MOVIE'. I haven't seen a lot of those films because I hate that type of film-making but I have seen 'SCARY MOVIE' and 'DATE MOVIE' and in my opinion they're two of the worst films ever made. With that said this film is slightly better. It's not quite as atrocious but it's still pretty bad.

The film stars Jenn Proske as Becca Crane, a young high school student who moves to Sporks with her father Sheriff Frank (Diedrich Bader) after her mother begins an affair with Tiger Woods. She feels like an outcast at first but quickly makes friends, including the reuniting with her childhood buddy Jacob (Christopher N. Riggi), and draws the attention of bad boy Edward (Matt Lanter). She falls for Edward even though he warns her he's dangerous and he quickly takes her home to meet his family and exposes his true identity as that of a vampire. His family quickly turns on Becca and tries to eat her, as well as other dangerous vampires in the area and Edward and Becca's true love is put to it's biggest test. If you know the first two 'TWILIGHT' films it pretty much follows the same basic storyline.

The film is full of juvenile humorless jokes that have been done hundreds of times before, especially by these filmmakers, it really scrapes the bottom of the barrel. There's absolutely no creativity or wit to the film at all. With that said the film is less painful to watch than others of this genre. It's not as disgusting or gross and the jokes aren't quite as bad. There's also a few jokes that are funny I have to say, enough that could fit in a ten minute short film but the film does provoke a couple laughs. Also the film's acting is actually better than the films it spoofs and Jenn Proske (in her debut film) does an extremely impressive job imitating Kristen Stewart (who starred as the character she mocks in the 'TWILIGHT' films and was actually the only one to give a good performance in that series), so she could be someone to watch out for in the future. While the film is really bad it's not one of the worst films I've ever seen, like similar type movies, and while I'll admit the 'TWILIGHT' films are a little better made than this I still found it slightly more enjoyable to watch.

Watch our review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqvCRlRn7qY

No, of course, his "genius", the actor, plot or soundtrack, this film is no different from all the other parodies. But for me this film is unique. Usually, I am one to be very opinionated and critical when it comes to the movies I watch, but this movie was an exception. It isn't a cinematic masterpiece but i considered it just a movie to relax and have a few laughs. I honestly was expecting to be disappointed from the very beginning, but it didn't "suck" and it wasn't like the previous parodies(epic movie, date movie, etc) Even I got sick and tired of the obsession with twilight so for them to make it the butt of every joke made it very enjoyable to watch. Though i must say, towards the end i felt like they ran out of ideas and just wanted it to end. None the less, GIVE IT A CHANCE AND WATCH IT FOR YOURSELF :)

review_title: Sucks the fun out of Vampires.
review_detailed_main:
It throws in a few funny jokes to keep you laughing throughout the movie but there was over-exaggeration in some scenes of the movie. It IS probably one of the best parodies of the 'Twilight' Series and the ability to merge two films together + capture the essence of those was done well.

It is a film that accommodates both people who are fan of the series or absolutely hate it. The portrayal of Becca Cullen by Jenn Proske was done to make her almost as likable as Bella Swan.

My key reason of watching the film? Matt Lanter, who I previously watched in 90210 and Cutting Edge 3. He pulled of the role and provided the audience with a few laughs. The only flaw was that he was covered in all that makeup.

Vampire Sucks is not as horrible as it's made out to be but it's definitely not Oscar material. It's a bearable film to say the least. Wouldn't recommend going to watch it at the cinema, just hire it at your local DVD store instead.

It's been a week since I attended a teen-centric, after-work screening of "Vampires Suck," and my usual punctuality in submitting a brief review on IMDb was met with a sort of instinctual resistance. Ultimately, I felt more than a little unqualified to critique something that pokes fun at a universe I view with indifference: Stephenie Meyer's "Twilight" books (and the subsequent film franchise). While the screening was not my idea (I agreed to accompany a female friend), I took what I knew of the cultural phenomenon (which is also apparently what the writing/directing duo of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer did), lowered my expectations, and prepared for the worst. The verdict? "Vampires Suck" wasn't the terrible waste of time I dreaded it would be: certain bits of crude slapstick connect, as does the subtle (and rarer) bits of wordplay; and Jenn Proske, who plays the film's Kristen Stewart stand-in, absolutely nails the actress's awkward twitches and lovelorn stares. That being said, this parody coasts largely on the name-brand recognition of its source rather than any genuine comedic impetus: at the end of the day, the name of the game is profiteering off "Twilight" before the phenomenon loses steam. As such, "Vampires Suck" is an inoffensive -- yet utterly disposable -- bit of cinema.

3.5 out of 10

I'm giving this a 10 only because it is unfair that it got so many 1 ratings. i think the Twilight saga fans came here and put those 1 ratings :)

As a spoof this movie pokes fun at the Twilight saga all right, so it is right on the money. Ok maybe I wouldn't pay money to see this movie but i'd watch it on TV anytime it was showing - it is funny enough
That's basically what it is. Definitely doesn't deserve a 3/10 which it scores right now.

review_title: A parody that just wasn't needed.
So bad, it hurts to watch
review_detailed_main:
A friend invited me over for a "junk movie", and I thought, how bad can it be? Watching a junk movie every now and then at least calibrates your understanding of the media machine; what kinda junk have they been grinding out lately? Well, I was aware, for example, that there's actually a publishing industry that's based on the idea that if you slam a bunch of senseless, touchie-feelie prose between a hard cover and give it a self-help-sounding title, lost souls will buy it to adorn their shelves with--and then wonder why life is still hell.

And it's just as true that if you assemble of coterie of hack "writers" to knock out a movie script rife with poorly sublimated aggression ("gags"), hire hungry actors, and apply some out-of-the-box production values, there are people who will shell out a few shekles and sit and derive some boredom-killing value from viewing it. Not watching it; viewing it.

OK, I'm being a little unfair: Somehow--and I really don't know how--certain personality types will get a cavalcade of laughs from this kind of watery, dim-witted tripe. My friend surprised me by showing that she was one of these types. I really need to get a better grade of friends.

The more primitive the humor, the more readily it cuts across cultural boundaries. Not everyone can understand the warm humor that derives from a piquant observation of life's experiences. But everyone can laugh at a wheelchair-bound guy being savagely beaten in a spirit of playful camaraderie. Or utterly gratuitous pop-culture references, with no plot anchoring, whatsoever.

Wait a minute: I started out trying to say something conciliatory, but it backfired.

My point is, that the real world of film production entails an understanding that there is a kind of economic undergirding: If people will watch it, people will produce it. That's all that can be said about this movie.

People: Stop watching these movies. There is still time.

review_title: Just youtube Twilight parody and it will better than this.
Awful, But a Little Better Than Other Friedberg-Seltzer Films
review_detailed_main:
I only found out later that "Vampires Suck" was another project of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, them of the "Disaster Movie" notoriety. However, during the film, you did already get the feeling that these were cut from the same cloth. There were so many stupid, lame and unfunny jokes and sight gags and pop references, all based on the already uneven "Twilight" films. They simply try too hard at being funny, that they wind up sucking more.

Based on the poster, you already know coming in that "Vampires Suck" will be a parody of the "Twilight" saga. Surprisingly, the film does follow the original quite closely, even with the make-up and location. The actors they have chosen, from the leads to the secondary characters, actually resemble the actors in the original.

The actors who played the three main characters really had a good time impersonating the original trio. The girl who played Becca Crane, Jenn Proske, had her Kristen Stewart perfectly, down to all those angsty mannerisms. Matt Lanter, whom we saw before as the lead guy in "Disaster Movie," also went to town, playing a tongue-in-cheek Robert Pattinson as the miserable Edward Sullen. Chris Riggi had the requisite tan and abs (and teats, haha!) of Jacob White, and the contractual obligation to remove his shirt every 15 minutes. These guys were actually quite funny as impersonators. Actually, I thought these smaller, subtler jokes in characterization were funnier than the big broad ones.

Overall, I still think this film is a waste of time and admission ticket. The comedy is lazy and groan-inducing. However, if you do decide to watch, there might a few gags which may make you giggle despite yourself (like the Black Eyed Peas joke with the bad vampires, or what the directors made the Wolf Pack do, or the prom sequence at the end). You may have fun with the spoof impersonation of the lead characters, like I did. We do have to find the silver lining in these instances, don't we?

Gee, a satire of the Twilight Movies...

I mean, were there no baby seals available to club? Or would they have put up too much of a fight? Talk about your easy targets.

This film is full of the vignettes you'd expect to see in a movie like this, the parts of the Twilight movies where the guys snickered while their girlfriends went oooh and ahhh. And of course, like most modern parodies, it couldn't resist at least one flatulence joke. Because Flatulence is funny, even the 500th time you've seen it. NOT!

Some bits were funny, like the werewolf who turned into a chihuahua. But most of them were the kind of predictable jokes you'd see in a movie like this, the only thing absent was Leslie Neilson, who passed away the week this came out on DVD.

review_title: You know what sucks about this movie? Everything
review_detailed_main: Vampire sucks is a movie that I do not recommend renting, buying, or even watching on TV. This will take up 2 hours of your life that you will never get back. I saw it since the twilight films were OK and I wanted to see how they made fun of them, yet they failed miserably. Yes, they made fun of them, and everything, but people need to remember it is a movie and the audience is the main critic. People argue that this was a hilarious film, yet I didn't even have a smirk in my face. HORRIBLE MOVIE. To bad. There were some scenes that had nothing to do with the saga, and the jokes were to plain. I know that giving this movie a 2 is harsh, but as a critic I think that it is what it deserves. Why am I not giving it a 1? The reason is that even thought it was awful, the main target was to make fun of the twilight saga, and it did, yet the movie itself was a failure.

review_title: Yes,Vampire's suck,but they aren't the only thing that sucks.
A Horrible Movie, but not as Bad as the movie it's spoofing
review_detailed_main: Vampires Suck is undoubtedly an awful movie to watch. It's another "Masterpiece" created by the Horrible movie directors of Friedberg and Seltzer. These guys have no idea how to make anything good, or even how to make anything humorous. They should be banned from the industry from making anything. And this movie is no exception. But why do I give it two stars instead of one? Because though Vampires Suck is a terrible film, its still a better movie than any of the Twilight movies. Yes, BETTER. The Twilight movies are the worst movies I've ever seen. Its mainly because of the horrible characters of Bella, Edward and Jacob who have no decent human qualities. It also ruins the lore of horror fantasy. Because of the Twilight movies, I will never find Vampires or Werewolves interesting ever again. Bottom Line, the Twilight movies are to me the lowest levels cinema can ever sink down to. Vampires Suck is better because it at least know the franchise it's spoofing is already horrible to begin with. Friedberg/Seltzer at least know that Twilight is terrible, so anything they do will be better than Twilight. Don't get me wrong, all of their movies are really bad. I just find them better than Twilight will ever be.

review_title: I wouldn't watch again, but its a parody; are you supposed to?
Now I regret that I spent the "Still better love story than Twilight" title on "New Moon"
review_detailed_main:
IMDb Bottom Rated Movies # 45 is a 'so bad it's good' over-the-top parody of "The Twilight Saga". Objectively, the movie is bad and ridiculous, but unlike the original, which with a budget of $ 400 million and serious intentions turned out to be bad, stupid and boring, this one with dozens of times smaller budget is deliberately bad and stupid and immeasurably entertaining. They dug up actors who mostly resemble those from the original franchise and mimic them pretty well, and Jenn Proske is both hotter and a better actress than gloomy Kristen Stewart's she skillfully mocks. The movie does not deserve the rating I gave it, but considering all of the above, I simply have to rate it at least one star more than the original.

6/10

review_title: Unlike all of their movies, this doesn't compete for "The Worst Friedberg & Seltzer Parody" !
Vampires Suck is another uneven movie spoof from Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer
review_detailed_main: Okay, having seen the previous "movie spoof" pictures-Epic Movie and Meet the Spartans-written and directed by Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, I knew right away to expect a "hit-or-miss" ratio when watching this, their latest comedy to take on the latest trends and topical one-liners, Vampires Suck. Based largely on the Twilight movies, we get a teenage girl named Becca (Jenn Proske) becoming the new girl in school who attracts the attention of the brooding vampire Edward (Matt Lanter). Even though I've yet to watch any of those Twilight films, I was familiar enough with that series' reputations to be partially amused by some of the situations. And it's a treat to see such familiar character actors like Diedrich Bader (who I first watched as Jethro on the movie version of The Beverly Hillbillies) and Ken Jeong of The Hangover do their stuff here. Still, it's a very uneven comedy with the usual punchlines on various headline-making celebrity scandals like that of Tiger Woods and the Kardashians that would render this very dated so fast, you'd probably be saying "Who?" by the time this goes to DVD in about three months! I mean, I liked when that squirrel was going to bite Edward's neck after he chomped into him and when Becca sang like Taylor Swift when playing the guitar on that motorcycle but, really, the lines and gags were sooo obvious and predictable that I was counting the minutes till it was all over. Oh well, at least the leads, especially the female, are such good eye candy...

review_title: As expected it Live up to its Name "SUCK"

review_detailed_main:
Hello all.

I have not written a review on this site for years. However, after having the misfortune to watch vampires suck, I felt compelled to write one. To get rid of all the bad karma.

Things looked promising after viewing the trailer. 'Are you the black eyed peas?', heh. And so I was suckered in. With the possible exception of one or two gags, this movie was totally unfunny. Not only that, it didn't make any sense. Mostly it didn't even get to the part 'there was the joke and it wasn't funny'. More like, 'wait, was that a joke? I'm unsure. What the hell is going on?' There is definitely no plot to the movie. Frankly it felt like the directors made efforts to create some sort of anti-plot. Every angle; murder, cops, father-daughter relation, alternate love interests, lycan-vampire rivalry, the introduction of lycans altogether; absolutely everything is presented and is an immediate dead end. Then there comes a sudden spiked club to the head and this stinker of a movie is put out of its misery in its typical nonsensical and unfunny way.

The only redeeming factor of this movie was the great acting performances. Seriously, they were good. I endured the whole movie clinching to the idea that at least the acting was good, like gasping for air. This maked me feel comfortable with giving it the 1/10. Would have been zero otherwise.

Unfunny, probably even if you're a retard.

review_title: This spoof is something along terrible
review_detailed_main:
This film is a complete make-up of "Twilight". The spoof is nothing good. Although it is different, it still doesn't satisfy anyone's present requirements for a good film.

The story is about a human teenage girl, Becca, who is torn between 2 boys - a vampire and a childhood friend.

The humour in the film is very basic, and can't pass as "professional". The film is made up of poorly crafted scenes, which wouldn't change my opinion on the movie, no matter what order they appear in. "Vampires Suck" is more or less like "Epic Movie" and "Disaster Movie". Out of these 3 films, none of them appealed to me 1 bit. The attempt at humour is incredibly bland, and in my opinion, there was not much effort put into the film compared to some other films that came out around the same time.

Ken Jeong made a fantastic appearance in "The Hangover" in 2009. He takes a small role in this film, but personally I think he would have been better taking on a larger role. The character of "Daro" is pointless and doesn't fit in with the story much.

I won't say the film was terrible, but as this film is a "Twilight" parody, you can see right from the start that it is mainly aimed towards "Twilight" fans. Despite watching it, It was a complete waste of my time. It is still an awful, unfunny film.

Some people may like this film, but in a few years time, I doubt there will be any more films like this, and if there are, I definitely wouldn't pay to see it.

This film was surprisingly not as awful as Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer's previous endeavors, however it is not nearly up to the level of a great farce like Airplane or even Kentucky Fried Movie. It echos the tone of MadTV often at times due to the cast, and although it could have been much hammier and painfully obvious,the leads primarily pull of the meta jokes with ease and elicit some of the best laughs. The pop culture references and slapstick gags are all groaners, however the jokes with the sole purpose of lampooning the Twilight phenomenon work and are actually clever with the actors competent delivery. However, despite the comedic chops behind some of these MadTV actors and even cameos from Ken Jeong and Dave Foley of Hangover and Kids in the Hall Fame, respectively, the movie ultimately leaves you wanting to watch their previous projects instead. Not terrible, but not worth the watch.

I'm giving this film a very generous 2 whole stars based on the Work Print release. It gets this by simply being better than the diabolically bad previous efforts of Jason Cuntberg and Aaron Shitzer. First of all, it manages to stay focused on the material it is supposed to be spoofing. Second, the lead actress is as good as, if not better than, Kristen Stewart. Third, some of the jokes do work, but most of them are obvious as Twilight is such an easy target. Finally, the pacing of the film is a lot better than that of Twilight or New Moon, showing that Twilight really squeezed out every drop of blood for it's sequel. There's also less of the celebrity "look alike" crap. Most of the jokes are still juvenile, obvious, painful, and poorly delivered, but it's certainly the best offering from these cinematic leeches thus far.

review_title: An hour and a half of my life I'll never get back.
review_detailed_main:
I'll admit I'm not the biggest fan of spoof films, but I rather enjoyed the original Scary Movie and Not Another Teen Movie. Scary Movie was the best one I've seen thus far and I gave it a 7. Compared to SM, this is absolutely inferior; which is a bit hard to understand considering these are the same writers (two of them anyway). Where are the Wayans bros. when you need them? I could definitely tell they are absent from this film w/o researching it first. The jokes are subpar (I gave a small chuckle twice, exactly twice), and the delivery is nowhere near as clever or smooth as SM. It's full of too many been-there-done-that gags, and after 7 or so spoof films within the past 10 years, they don't carry the same punch they used to.

I think somewhere around the 45 minute mark I fell asleep until the last 10 minutes of the movie. But the kids I took to the theater liked it. They're all 10 and under by the way. I doubt anyone over the age of 12 who has any taste in comedies will be able to sit through this in its entirety. Total waste of time, but I expected as much.

I really enjoyed this. The only thing I knew about the books was that they were causing tweener and young teen (girls, mostly; my 15 year old son would have no part of them...) to actually read books, you know, just for fun! "That can't be bad," I thought.

When my wife bought the first Twilight film home on a rented DVD, I actually was surprised to like it: most teens could relate to one of the main characters, I'd bet, or would at least admit to having "friends like that". (I mean, not quite undead / shape-shifters of course, but certainly "different", "alone", angst-ridden, confused...). I didn't care for the second installment, but then I rarely like sequels.

I usually am not that fond of parodies either, but this one had me laughing from beginning to end.

What amazed me about this one was that it works as parody even if you like the originals, which I think is very unusual. (Some of the reviews here claim you could only like it if you hated the originals, others said you'd like it MORE if you liked the originals...). I kind of think it might work even if you'd never seen a Twilight movie.

While I've not read the books this movie might in some ways be truer to the source than the movies it lampoons. ("I feel safe with you. Not like with Edward..."). I didn't get that from Twilight.

Finally, as has been duly noted, the leads were TERRIFIC at mimicking the characters in the original, particularly the ones playing Becca (why the name change though?), Edward, Becca's Dad, and Edward's sister.

Somewhere in the script wilderness this was bound to be written. Unfortunately it also turned out a sure-fire reality. Given the awkwardness of the "Twilight" series with shiny white veggie vampires, boring chicks to die for and an eternal love-story with a man-pooch as a third party, you just knew deep down that there would be a spoof of the series.

And as sure as vampires teeth are shiny low and behold: the suck has come to being. The typecast "Airplane" jokes densely populate the genre it is over-flooded with the expected low-level humour based on low punches, cheap shots and obligatory word jokes (i.e. regarding Edward's bling bling). Nonetheless sometimes on a new moon the rare heavy hitter does manage to transform the typical jokes into ones more fleshed-out and rather effective. Some of the obvious, yet more subtle jabs, at the movie are also present, so I found myself weirdly endeared for brief stints of the movie. I especially found myself engaged by the final act when the plot actually manages to take me off-guard with the scene of the 'final battle'. The audacious natural goofiness of Ken Jeong as vampire numero uno must have also influenced my overall perception: I just can't not love the dude, however ridiculous his given role.

An additional star for Jenn Proske as our hoariness for actually turning out to be a more believable and considerably less irritating actor than Kristen Stewart (aka Bella Swan in the "Twilight" franchise).

review_title: The film never stops to suddenly jump into making fun of another film
When you hear a title like vampire sucks you expect vampire jokes

review_detailed_main: If you want to watch a really bad film. This is perfect for you. I don't have much to say about vampires suck because it is awful. The acting is poor. I enjoyed the twilight films and i find this very offensive to those. Don't bother watching this film. It is a complete waste of time and you would no doubt find much better things to do then watch this movie. I didn't even watch all of this film and i still found it to diabolical to watch. I watched this film with my family and they found it to bad to watch it just as much as i did. By the way if you are a twilight fan this will defiently not be for you. It will put you complitely of it for a while.

review_title: Not very good and less so if you don't know the Twilight films

review_detailed_main:
Vampires Suck is not a very good spoof at all is practically the same as watching Twilight with worse acting and dumb fart jokes. In terms of recent spoofs, this film may be a little better than those unfunny Meet the Spartans and Disaster Movie, but that's not saying much. The only joke I really liked here is when the one girl said that the movie would bomb, but camera pans up to saying Twilight Breaking Dawn part 1.

Friedberg and Seltzer has to making these films because they're stupid and not funny. They need to make something like the Scary Movies series. This film basically has the same plot as Twilight with the exception of a few lame name changes.

The acting is pretty awful. Except for the main girl who actually captures Bella's essence, everyone else was just painfully awful.

Overall, this is a pitiful excuse for a movie and this should have never been made. It's bad that people lose all our IQ by watching films like this. I don't mind spoofs but they have to be good quality. I'm not the one to trash on movies but on films like these, I will. I rate this hideous film a 3/10.
Do I have to say it what can we expect from the team that bought us the piece of crap that was Epic movie

review_title: Not as funny, and whole lot of nonsense

review_detailed_main:
This movie was terrible. Nothing was funny. The only good thing I will say is the girl that played Becca had Kristen Stewart's weird pouty faces down. The movie combines elements of the first two Twilight movies. It just kinda bounces around and when they need to, they make up their own plot lines. For example, Becca doesn't go to Italy, instead the ancient vamps show up to their vampire themed prom. As a side note, Frank, Becca's dad, is played by Jethro Bodine from the Beverly Hill Billies move from the 1990s. When I first heard that guy speak, I was like, that sounds like Jethro, so I looked it up on IMDb.

FINAL VERDICT: Only watch if you want to see what one of the worst movies ever made looks like.

review_title: This movie needed to be made :)
review_detailed_main:
In my few years, (I'm 19), I've never seen something as popular, yet as terrible as the Twilight movies. They are the ultimate proof in this world that just because something is popular, doesn't mean that it's any good. This movie is brilliant in that it takes all of the flaws, awkward moments, and overall ridiculousness of the series and magnifies it. This movie is so self aware that its just brilliant. I have to say that I didn't enjoy Date Movie, Epic Movie, Meet The Spartans, or Disaster Movie at all. In fact, I think they are terrible. They are perfect examples of how to waste dozens of millions of dollars on overdone, unfunny parodies of love-able movies. The twist with Vampires Suck, though, is that it is a parody of something that, deep down inside, we all really do hate. (Unless you're an obsessed teenage girl with the IQ of a tomato, no offense) So, please, if you're one of those persons who listens to everyone else's opinions, please don't. Rotten Tomatoes gives this movie a 3%, which is ridiculous. This is an insult, because they gave The Last Airbender an 8%. This film deserves at least a 75%. This movie will make you laugh until you crap thunder, and if a movie makes me laugh more than 15 times, I like it. (A couple recent examples of really funny movies are Date Night, The Other Guys, Dinner For Schmucks, She's Out Of My League, The A-Team, and Hot Tub Time Machine.)

So, have a nice day, go see this movie, and don't be uptight and not accepting, have an open mind, and you'll laugh yourself silly. This movie was better than all of the Twilight movies combined.

review_title: Much better than I would have expected!
review_detailed_main:
Lets be honest..almost every movie-fan that's watched epic cinematic failures like Meet the Spartans , Epic Movie etc are going to think Vampires Suck should be avoided at all costs.

They couldn't be more wrong.

YES there are a few gross-out moments in this and YES the inescapable potty- humor moment here and there, but other than that this movie is completely hilarious. I couldn't help but find myself laughing every 10 minutes and thats a pretty good track record for a modern day movie spoof. I'm not a Twilight fan..and if you're not either, chances are..you will enjoy this movie. It's light-hearted, doesn't attempt to be more than it is and entertains.

The funniest thing about it is that the actors playing in it almost do a better job playing Edward, Bella and Jacob than the original cast do. The movie doesn't suffer from attempts at poking fun of 10-15 different movies at once and maybe thats why it works this once.

They just focus on just making fun of two movies in the Twilight series and I think they did a pretty damn good job of it. I hate to say..I really do..but I might just go see this movie a second time. It's honest to god that funny.

review_title: While it isn't the best spoof out there...
This movie sucks more than Twilight.
review_detailed_main:
I am not a big fan of the Twilight books or films. I read one or two books when I was 13, enjoyed one of them and went to see the first movie in the cinema and it broke my heart in two. They ruined the books, the characters and actually made me quit reading the remaining books. Since there are so many new vampire movies it really became a hype so a parody about vampire movies would actually be really funny. Well, this movie isn't. Not. At. All.

They basically copied the whole Twilight story, so it is actually as watching the Twilight movies but then stuffed with bad, tacky jokes and throw-cake-in-face humor that a lot of American comedies have. I think it would be a lot funnier if they came up with their own vampire story, so it actually would be something refreshing to see instead of sitting and staring at a bad version of Twilight. The references to famous singers or actors are not doing a great job, there was no single moment that I had to laugh or even smile during this movie. I was watching it waiting for it to end so I could write this sorry review about it. Jenne Proske, playing Bella, could impersonate her very well and was the only thing in this movie that actually made me think 'good job'.

Satire is supposed to be witty, revealing, insightful. Sadly this title is every bit as bad as the drivel it clumsily attempts to ridicule.

Pathetic jokes about flatulence and so on are a substitute for insightful comment and there is plenty to comment on. The unthinking formulaic nature of industrial film making, the creation of a stereotypical youth culture and a lot more besides.

So much could have been said. Instead what we get is exposition, cheap stunts and gags that could well have been dreamed up by a eight year old and his/her friends backed by obvious, predictable jokes and ersatz satire that is really little more than tarted up cynicism. But then this is what happens when you get an industry that attempts to satirize itself. It misses the mark either because it has no idea what it needs to say or does not really want to say, for very obvious reasons, what it already knows.

A one out of ten and its barely worth even that.

review_title: Vampires Suck and so does the show. SPOILER ALERT
review_detailed_main: This was one of those movies where the ending wasn't good, the last half of the movie wasn't good, and somebody forgot this was supposed to be a funny show. It could have been funny but having a werewolf chase a cat two or three times ceases to be funny. The ending could of been good, but instead of letting the lead vampire get a club to the head, they had to have Becca show her fangs. Just let the damn movie end. At least the club to the head would be a shocker like a girl getting run over by a car at the end of Scarry Movie. This was just not very well written and was just a "Let's make some money" and turn people off to satires completely.

review_title: Formula's Dead but the Idea is Undead
review_detailed_main:
We can call "Vampires Suck" a guilty pleasure for those of us that have hated or didn't understand the "Team Edward" or "Team Jacob" fad, and have hated that pale guy with the weird eyes staring at us whenever we went in to a theatre, a book store, a clothing store...just about anywhere, really.

I suppose the plot would make more sense if we had actually seen the "Twilight" movies, but I could piece together enough to make it funny. A girl named Becca Crane falls for Edward Sullen, which causes a rift with Jacob White, and chaos falls after that and leads into a rather pointless middle and finally a fulfilling ending with the "Teams" battling each other.

I didn't like "Epic Movie" or "Disaster Movie" because I enjoyed most of the films that were being lampooned. But this is not so in "Vampires Suck", so all in all it is a sound bad-summer-comedy that disappoints, but it was made to disappoint.

I'd wait for the rental, and wait for a day where you don't want to think at all.

review_title: all right...could have been WAY better
review_detailed_main: OK so lets be honest it was never going to be that great considering vampires suck was a spoof based on one of the worst vampire movies ever made. still it could have been better, there were a few funny moments in the film (only recognisable if you watch the twilight films first though)however i found that the majority of the humour was too obvious and crude to be really funny and simply portrayed a sense of immaturity and lack of imagination from both director and writer. however the actors made a commendable effort (especially the girl who mimicked Kirsten Stewarts appalling acting perfectly) its a shame they were considerably let down by the scathing incompetence of the director...the movie had potential...but in the end became obsolete and pointless. a real disappointment

review_title: Doesn't suck as badly as it could have done, but still dire
review_detailed_main:
Asking me which Aaron Seltzer & Jason Friedberg film I prefer is a bit like asking if I'd rather take a bullet in the brain or in the chest. Until yesterday, my answer would probably have been "Date Movie", but as of today, and somewhat surprisingly, my answer would probably change to "Vampires Suck". That's not really much of a statement though - it's a bit like saying that Colonel Gadaffi is not quite as evil as Saddam Hussein. It might be true, but neither of them are particularly nice people, and the same theory holds true of Friedberg & Seltzer's works - just because this one is only in the gutter while all their other movies are completely down the drain isn't much of a way to compare them, but its just about the only way I have.

Seltzer & Friedberg seem to be rather elusive characters, and even when it comes to extra features on DVDs, I can't recall ever having seen a picture of them anywhere. I'm beginning to think that like the infamous "Alan Smithee", that Friedberg & Seltzer don't really exist. I'd love to see them do an audio commentary for one of their films which is just a continuous loop of "We're sorry. We're so, so sorry." - it would almost make the film worth buying!! To be fair though, they have got at least one thing right this time around. Instead of trying to squeeze in about ten different movie spoofs into one film plus a random pop culture reference every other minute, the writers have taken the wise step of only spoofing one franchise - the popular "Twilight" saga. They haven't completely left out the gratuitous pop culture stuff, but it's a step in the right direction - it at least feels like one coherent movie with an actual plot, rather than ten movies shoehorned into one coming out as an incoherent mess. Also presumably, Carmen Electra didn't need rent money the month this was being filmed, as she is thankfully absent from our screens this time around.

I usually give over-promoted franchises a miss - at least until a lot of the fanfare and hoo-ha dies down around them, which is one reason I came very late to "Friends" and "Ally McBeal" on TV (and still avoid "Ugly Betty") and the same reason I avoided "Lord of the Rings" and "Harry Potter" for a long while and have never really taken to them. Unlike my sister, who has read the Twilight books and watched the films religiously, I barely know who Robert Pattinson is, and I wouldn't recognise Kristen Stewart if she walked down the street and flashed her breasts at me. The Twilight franchise probably is ripe for spoofing, but Seltzer & Friedberg probably aren't the best people Hollywood could have appointed to the role, with the result that this movie isn't half as good as it could have been. Luckily, it's not half as bad as it could have been either. And there is at least one person who deserves at least some credit, and that is lead actress Jenn Proske, although whether she is capable of anything more than Kirsten Stewart impersonations remains to be seen, but if I was to give her one piece of future career advice, it would probably be to stay away from any future Friedberg & Seltzer productions and try something more challenging instead.

I'm not really sure why I continue to fund Seltzer and Friedberg by paying to watch their movies - probably out of morbid curiosity and just to see if they really are getting any worse and whether or not they will ever churn out anything half-decent. "Vampires Suck" isn't it, but it is a step in the right direction. 2/10

review_title: Best spoof movie out there right now
review_detailed_main:
I started watching this movie with the same mind frame as most future viewers: "Oh God, this is going to be like Epic Movie, Meet the Spartans, with the potty humor and endless pop culture references.." I was pleasantly surprised. There were only about 4 pop culture references and 2 potty jokes. Yes. You read this correctly. I'm thinking the directors learned from their mistakes from the past spoof movies and definitely put some work into this one.

I'm not saying everyone will find this funny. You have to at least know most of the Twilight series, whether you like the series or not. It helps a lot, otherwise you may not get some of the jokes.

The actress that played Becca (Bella) was spot on - with all of Kristen Stewart's tics (hair touching, blinking) and she sounded almost exactly like her. I loved the jokes about teen angst, cheesy teen romance movies, and..well you'll have to watch it.

You may think it's dumb but it's funny dumb, which is entertaining to me. Go in with an open mind and you will be entertained.

STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday Morning

Having always displayed a sophisticated sense of humour, I was drawn to Vampire's Suck from the trailer, which cleverly plays like an advert for another unbearable Twilight instalment, only for a fart gag to suddenly break in and hilariously shatter any such illusion. Another blissfully short effort from the modern Proft/Zucker, Vampire's Suck keeps itself moving just by not having any illusions about itself and just being enjoyably silly through-out, without the gross unpleasantness of Disaster Movie or just the lameness of Epic Movie. It keeps itself in the times by the obligatory pop culture references, including a politically incorrect pop at Lady Gaga...I don't want to talk like it's some great masterpiece, but by S & F's standards, you can't complain. ***

This movie really sucks. I am a fan of the early Twilight movies. I am also a fan of Dracula (1931). One of my favorite comedy movies is Dracula dead and loving it. It was funny and did not insult the fans of any Dracula movie. And it did not put down any of the Dracula movies. This movie insulted the fans of the early Twilight movies. And it did put down the early Twilight movies. But the worst thing about this movie is that it is a comedy and it is not funny. If a vampire movie is not going to be funny is should a lest be scary. This movie is not scary. This movie is badly written. Do not wast time and money. Do not see this movie. The girl who played Bella is very pretty, But still the movie is awful. They will have to do a lot more then find a pretty girl to get me to like a movie. This is one of the wort comedies ever.

review_title: Dumb humor and I love dumb humor
Starts good, but dies out quickly
Dislike Twilight? Good Laugh. Otherwise, stay away. Far, far away.
review_detailed_main:
If you dislike the Twilight films, as I have, you will find this movie somewhat enjoyable and funny. However, in all, this movie is just as good as Scary Movie 3 (which, was terrible). Few jokes were truly funny, the rest were poor attempts at it and made almost no sense as to why they were done in the first place.

However, where this movie really shines is in its parody of Twilight; it truly copies the style of the Twilight films through and through: starts off a tad interesting, but half an hour in, you're bored and want to turn it off. Of course, it does do good parodies of the insane and completely laughable themes of the first two Twilight movies. In all, if you dislike the Twilight movies, go ahead and give this a go for a few good chuckles. Otherwise, don't bother watching it.

Spoof movies used to be a bit of a rarity in Hollywood but that certainly isn't the case anymore. In the 2000s we seem to have a new parody film released every week and it is quite common to have a parody film floating around Top 10 box office lists these days.

The recent popularity in parody films seemed to start with the financially successful Scary Movie franchise. I quit like the first Scary Movie film, a spoof mainly focused on the Scream franchise also parodying other popular 90s movies. The script written by the Wayans' brothers was reasonably well written, entertaining, witty and often silly spoofing 90s movies and pop culture often at the same time. The delivery of this comedy material was also good, in particular from the actress Anna Farris who went on to have a very successful career in comedy films.

The success of Scary Movie meant we got Scary Movie 2 then Scary Movie 3 and so on. Unfortunately, each sequel was much worse than the film it followed. Now we are up to Scary Movie 5 and the franchise is totally unwatchable. While the Scary Movie films were being released there was a whole bunch of awful spoof films being released across Hollywood with films like Not Another Teen Movie, Date Movie, Epic Movie, Disaster Movie and so on. It makes sense for Movie Studios to make these films, they are cheap to make, get a good return at the box office and it doesn't seem to matter whether they are good or not as people go to see them regardless.

When I first heard about Vampires Suck I had very low expectations, after seeing so many of these terrible 2000s spoof films I have lost all faith in the genre. Vampires Suck is a parody based on the Twilight film franchise. I quit like the Twilight films, they are entertaining but at times can be little ridiculous giving a lot of potential for someone to write a funny spoof film. Maybe Vampires Suck could be this film, unfortunately it was not.

It was an incredibly painful experience watching Vampires Suck. It's lazily written as the plot is very closely based on the first two twilight films almost copying rather than parodying, occasionally slipping I the odd pop culture reference for a cheap laugh which fails miserably every time. The only small positive from this film I could give was Jenn Proske's performance as she did a good job parodying Kristen Stewart's awkward performance as Bella Swan in the Twilight films.

Vampires Suck is supposed to be a comedy and I can honestly say I never laughed once through the entire 82 minutes. With a lot of bad comedy films these days the only funny lines are used up in the trailer. Having just watched the trailer for Vampires Suck I can say that there wasn't anything funny in there either, the only joke was on me because if only I had seen the trailer for Vampires Suck first I would have known it was terrible as originally thought and would not have wasted 82 minutes of my life watching this nonsense.

With this current stream of terrible 2000s spoof films, Vampires suck is probably the worst one so far which is a hell of a statement in its own right. There are 644 words in this review and it would take the average reader 4 minutes to read that many words. By reading my review you will now be well aware that this is a shockingly terrible film and certainly one to avoid. Vampires Suck is 82 minutes long and by avoiding this film, misusing the 4 minutes it has taken you to read this review, I have saved you 78 minutes of your life and for that all I have left to say is your welcome.

Vampires Suck (2010) This yet another spoof, this time it a spoof of Twilight' movie.

I do seem to like a lot Spoof movies, such as all the scary movies, Shriek If You Know What I Did Last Friday the Thirteenth, Not another teen movie, Superheor movies, i did enjoy those movies

I did not like date movie, Epic Movie, Disaster Movie or Stan Hellsing and i have not seen Meet the Spartans.

However for Vampires Suck, I did not hate and I did not love it and I did enjoy the movie.

The movie start of really poor, some of the jokes are way over the top and do not work, but after 20 mins of the movie.

It did get a bit better then were some okay jokes scenes which made me laugh few times but it's much better then the god awful Disaster Movie and StanHellsing put together but not as good as any of the Scary movies or even Superhero movie.

If you don't like spoof, skip it, and if you liked Shriek If You Know What IDid Last Friday the Thirteenth, then you might like this too .

i going this 4 and half out 10 lol

This movie seems a parody of twilight. I think the plot is boring. I'm also tired of seeing Asian guys appearing on film just for a few seconds as sort of targets to create fun with. This movie, whether intentionally or not, again stereotyped asian guys as marginalised group to create humor with.

review_title: It mocks Twilight, therefore it is technically perfection.
Enjoyed it better than actual Twilight
review_detailed_main: i saw this for free so no i didn't pay to see it. but what do you expect from a spoof movie? just mindlessly watch it with the crowd and laugh along. laughing is good for you. i found this more entertaining than the actual twilight movie (i don't like twilight). overall, there were about 2 really funny scenes with some obvious jokes thrown in throughout. some people really laughed hard though all the way through. also, the actor playing jacob in this is way better than taylor lautner and i feel like taylor should have been in the spoof (sorry, had to say it). the main actress has kristen stewart's mannerisms down to a T to the point where it actually started annoying me like when stewart does them. the ending is particularly funny. good luck.

review_title: If you hate Twilight this one's for you

review_detailed_main:
A spoof movie that focuses, as you have already guessed, on the recent flood of vampire movies. Of course it revolves around a teenage girl that has crush on the mysteriously pale boy in the same class as her. A lot of jokes and puns evolve around that central story, but a few other movies get a kick too.

It is tricky to do a real good and successful spoof, and Vampire Sucks don't really come close to that target. It does got a few jokes that are quite fun, but too many are of poor quality and the movie is just too diluted to really work. I guess that to make this really work you've got to either really love or really hate the vampire franchises...

This is up there with the worst movies in the history of mankind, so many ridiculous scenes that failed to make you laugh and lots of really crude humour and lines that just aren't appropriate in modern society. Love a good comedy, and really like movies like flying high, which this is trying to be. But is epically bad.

The police Sergeant Dad comments on his daughters breasts, there's closely related siblings, making out and more toilet, humour and ridiculous nonsense than a 10-year-old could dream up. It blows my mind that this movie was created, but it was an area. A real shocker. Make sure you don't watch this.

review_title: To those who like this movie: Go to hell
review_detailed_main: To Jason Friedberg and Aron Seltzer: Please stop making movies. Your films are not funny, they never were funny, they never will be funny! If you can't even do a spoof of Twilight right then you are a horrible disgrace to the art of film making. It's not that the jokes in this film grew old months ago, they grew old years ago! You still have the stupid door in your face joke, the poop joke, and constant unfunny references to things like shows and other movies. For example, there is one scene where the girl ask who the Edward spoof guy is (His acting is even worse than Robert Pattison's look like Leonardo DiCaprio) and her friend list a bunch of names, the Bella spoofer says "No, not the douchebags from the Jersey Shore". Do you understand how insulted I felt to be watching this bs? If anyone you know thinks that this is a funny, well made film you have my permission to smack them with a baseball bat.

review_title: I Didn't quite watch this movie.

review_detailed_main:
The point of a spoof movie is that it is supposed to make fun of other movies and make you laugh. Although Vampires Suck sort of succeed on the first, they utterly fail on the second. This is not funny.

In the entire movie there are like 2 or 3 jokes that land, and I think I smiled once or twice. That is it. The only thing that works with this movie is Jenn Proske and her demeanour which is dead-on and exactly like Kirsten Stewart's wooden lack of talent. Jenn is clearly a much better actress than Kristen, and her character is the only one that work in this entire movie. The rest are badly acted, badly written, badly directed, or a combo of all three.

This is not the worst movie ever. In fact this is almost watchable, but since it fails on delivering on the laughs, and since camera work, sound design and a lot of other factors also fail, I think a 3/10 seem very reasonable.

Its a shame really. Making fun of Twilight and similar should be a slam dunk, and as mentioned Jenn is excellent in her role, so this could have easily been a great fun movie. But sadly another failure in a long line of failed spoof movies. Aren't people in Hollywood funny anymore?

review_title: Great parody/lampoon is better than reviewed
review_detailed_main:
From the opening 5 minutes this film sets its theme. In my opinion there are several laugh out loud scenes and subtle jokes that make this film a wonderful time filler for pure enjoyment. No stress no mess.

I can't understand why some people are so hateful. It's not as though there were uncouth jokes about sensitive subjects. The film focuses strictly on parodying the "Twilight" films.

I'm just saying... lighten up.

review_title: Funny parody of an over-hyped movie
review_detailed_main:
First of all, the movie is from the creators of "Spy Hard", "Scary Movie 1", "Date Movie", "Epic Movie", "Meet the Spartans" and "Disaster Movie". So, if you didn't liked these films, you won't like this one, either. If you liked them, you'll have your fun with this spoof.

I want you to know, that you have to see the movies "Twilight" and "New Moon" first, before you watch this one. You may get some jokes, but most of them will seem odd to you.

The thing is, the movie is not intelligent or something, and the gags are very simple.

Most of the jokes are vulgar, gross or violent. The movie doesn't push the PG-13 rating, however. All of it is done in a comic fashion and, especially for the violence, it is that comical and unrealistic that every teenager will handle the film.

If you liked the writer's previous works, you'll like this one, too. Don't expect something like Mel Brook's movies - rather something like "Epic Movie".

I watched this movie in theater and i laughed quite a lot.

I recommend the movie for children 14 and up. It has some violent scenes but the scenes are quite unrealistic. The movie also has some rather strong sexual content, such as a SM scene, a sex doll and frequent sexual talk. The unrated version actually isn't much stronger.

review_title: This film is daft in every respect!
review_detailed_main: Oh my God... This movie has literally got to be one of the worst films I have ever seen in my life! Just the plot of doing a comedic remake of the brilliant (Twilight Saga) it just makes me sick to see it being re-made in a way that just doesn't suit the theme for the film. I kind of get the fact that some people may have actually wanted to see this film come out or even here about it being made. When I heard I was so excited for it! Then I watched and thought to myself 'Well this is the stupidest adaptation I have ever seen!' I eventually got to the end of the movie and then turned off the TV as soon as possible! I would not suggest this film to big time Vampire Movie Fans.

Vampires Suck

Why would a girl ever love a vampire? With all those pointy planks, they could never build her a picket fence. And if they could, when would they build it...at night?

Unfortunately, the chaste chick in this Twilight Saga spoof did not heed said advice.

When an introverted youth, Becca (Jenn Proske), moves to a small-town to live with her father (Diedrich Bader), she finds herself immersed in a bizarre love triangle with a vampire, Edward Sullen (Matt Lanter), and a werewolf, Jacob (Christopher N. Riggi). To make matters worse, the local vampire clan and wolf pack are at odds with one another, leaving Becca torn.

By only lampooning the Twilight series, and not referencing every other movie, the makers of these insipid spoof movies–along with their comedic cameos–have finally done a so-so job.

Regardless, though, of whomever Becca chooses, breast-feeding their offspring will be a bitch. (Yellow Light)

Finally a spoof of one of my top 5 worst movies ever, Twilight. Normally I don't do American spoofs because mostly I can't laugh with their jokes. I'm more into British humor. But my children gave it to me for my birthday and noticing that it was made by the Scary Movie franchise guys I thought to give it a try.

Yes, Scary movie. Everybody loved part 1 but it was downhill from their on. And this one wasn't good at all. The jokes are so stupid that toddlers will have fun with it but my face moved only for a few times. I never had any tears in my eyes from laughing. As a spoof on Twilight that is okay, it's even recognizable. It follows the same lines but the jokes just didn't work. And they all looked like the Twilight people but the acting itself wasn't that good after all, they exaggerated sometimes that it really got annoying. The sleepwalking scene didn't work for me. Or when Edward is going to bite Becca she has written on her neck, bite here. Really, is this a joke? I even tortured myself by watching the extended version, sadly it just didn't work. I guess teenagers who hate Twilight will have a big laugh with it, some jokes were mediocre, the others really bad. If I had a closer look towards the title I should have known enough...

Gore 0/5 Nudity 0/5 Effects 1/5 Story 2/5 Comedy 1/5

Becca Crane returns to live with her sheriff father in her childhood home in Sporks, Washington. It's a spoof of the Twilight movies. She falls for the sparkling vampire Edward Sullen.

Some may say Twilight is too awful to be spoofed. I sympathize but I don't think bad movies are unspoofable. In fact, bad genre can be great spoof. Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer are responsible for the series of recent bad spoof movies. This one won't win any great awards. There is something strange about this one. It follows the Twilight movie quite closely and I wonder who this movie is written for. With non-fans who never saw the Twilight franchise, they would never understand the comparison. With Twilight fans, they wouldn't want to laugh at their own fandom. So it's stuck in no-man's land. As for the lead Jenn Proske, she plays it as a demur Bella which is fine but she's not actually that funny. She's not big enough. She's basically an actress who normally plays the lead's quiet friend. She's cute but lacks the big charisma to fill the screen. There are some passable attempts at jokes but nothing that really hits. Without a big lead or something imaginative, this spoof lacks the armor to deflect the expected slings and arrows.

From the makers of the feeble Disaster Movie and Epic Movie comes Vampires Suck that spoofs the Twilight saga and is a step up from Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer's previous efforts.

Becca Crane (Jenn Proske) shows up in a gloomy town to live with her overly protective sheriff father Frank (Diedrich Bader). At her new high school, Becca is torn between two guys, the brooding ashen faced Edward Sullen (Matt Lanter) who is a vampire, and hairy handed Jacob White (Chris Riggi) who seems to be a shaggy werewolf.

What the movie gets right is following the template closely of Twilight and New Moon with the actors Lanter, Proske and Riggi channelling their original counterparts closely. Lanter's Edward really looks spooky close to Robert Pattinson. The set design and atmosphere again makes you think that the directors have put an effort in getting the look right before sending up the films.

What lets it down are the scatter-gun jokes and sight gags with random pop culture jokes which ages the film quickly and you might not even understand them if you live outside of the USA. The jokes are thrown about in the hope the audience might find some of them funny.

The Jacob dog jokes are mildly amusing such as him suddenly chasing cats and urinating on a fire hydrant but many of the gags miss their mark.

The Airplane and The Naked Gun films established the benchmark for parody films and they have also shown that they are not easy to replicate. In that regard Vampires do suck.

review_title: Not a Good Movie, But I Still Got Some Laughs
review_detailed_main:
Of course it is immature and not worth spending an atrocious amount of money on at a big theater, but it can still give ya some laughs. It's not over the top horrible like Date Movie or anything like that and it's a heck of a lot funnier. I was unfortunately in a theater with loads of little middle-schoolers and they found the film hilarious and I felt like it was appropriate for their ages. Even I, who is 20, had a few laughs at some of the parts and was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't the worse movie I had seen or even close.

I still prefer it over the actual Twilight movies. The acting is the exact same, but at least I get a few laughs this way.

review_title: Funny spoof of the Twilight saga...
review_detailed_main: 1st watched 9/11/2011 – 7 out of 10 (Dir-Jason Friedberg & Aaron Seltzer): Funny spoof of the Twilight saga that tried to emulate much of the first movie and does a good job of that plus adds in humor and gags that keep you laughing almost throughout. It does get a little lacking in the last half hour and ends too abruptly, in my opinion, but otherwise is pretty successful at what it was trying to accomplish. It starts out with a scene, that is later repeated and skipped(because we already saw it once) that is showing us what Becca, the young mis-understood girl, would do to save the hunky, albino vampire, Edward and then we are shown her moving in with her dad to a small town in Washington(like the Twilight movie). The gags start at the very beginning with the dad saying in-appropriate things to the daughter and don't stop til the end – where young girls fighting over the main characters end the movie with the last laugh. There are a few homages to other movies like "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", and believe-it-or-not "Alice In Wonderland", but mostly this is about the Twilight saga. I liked the first Twilight movie, and I liked this spoof of that movie. This talented writing/directing team of Jason Friedberg & Aaron Seltzer surprised me with this very good comedy effort and I hope to see more from them.

As can be expected, this spoof has some slapstick cheesy humor, B-list actors, and a plot that jumps around to get in as much it can in less than 90 minutes (because no one wants to watch these types of movies for that long). It even takes stabs at other vampire shows and real-life recent events. But it does plainly tell every Twilight watcher (especially towards teenage girls) what's so silly about those movies. Oddly enough Jen Proske as "Becca Crane" does a better job spoofing Kristin Stewart than K Stew can do "Bella". It would have been better if there were more laughs, which is why I recommend you watch the unrated version as at least it gets a couple more laughs due to vulgarity. Every teenage girl who watched the Twilight series should be forced to watch this movie....it might help snap them back to reality....before it's too late.

review_title: Most of the gags will induce eye-rolls not laughs
review_detailed_main:
TL/DR: The film is knowingly campy (and not in a good way). The zany attempts at humor feel forced. It's borderline schlock.

I think the jokes would have been funny in a Mad Magazine format (with their satirical artwork style). They don't work that well in this live-action parody. While Jenn Proske does a fine job, WAY too much of the humor is just lame. Most of the cast hails from Smarmsville, the worst being Ken Jeong in a cringe-worthy performance. While there ARE a few LOL moments, one would have to be a dedicated B-movie fan to want to sit through the entire film.

Part of the problem is that if one removes some of the over-the-top absurdity, aspects of the film become disturbing. Take the rampant bullying of Becca Crane (Jenn Proske) for example. While the film isn't overtly mean-spirited, it does contain some characters that may cause you to wince instead of laugh.

I give this 4.5 stars for mild (but uneven) entertainment, MINUS half a star for Ken Jeong. That's four (4) stars total.

Even in 2023, i still laugh at it. I dont know why its rate are so low... YOU MUST WATCH IT. It's a parody of Twilight. And it's hilarious. Cast are so good. The references are well and if you are bored and you want to watch something funny this will be one of the best choices for you to watch. (It still says my review is so short so i'll add something stupid to fill this... so you don't have to read this part... I don't even know what else to add. JUST LET ME SUBMIT IT... OKAY SO HOW ARE YOU? IF YOU STILL READING THIS YOU DESERVED TO BE ASKED HOW YOU ARE. ANYWAY FROM NOW I CARE FOR YOU CUZ YOU STILL READING THIS...)(FINALLY IT'S OVER...)

Becca Crane (Jenn Proske) moved to Sporks to live with her clueless father (Diedrich Bader), who is the sheriff as well. Becca slowly realized that there is Vampires in Sporks. Becca finds herself falling in love with Edward Sullen (Matt Lanter), who happens to be a vampire as well going to her high school. She becomes friends with Jennifer (Anneliese van der Pol), a fast talking teen slut. Becca is also in danger, when three vampires (Arielle Kebbel, Charlie Weber and B.J. Britt) are after her. Edward saved her from one of the vampire attacks and Jacob (Christopher N. Riggi) also saved Becca from those attacks. But Jacob is a werewolf, who changes into a Chihuahua (!). But Jacob is in love with Becca. Now Becca has to choose between Edward and Jacob.

Directed by Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, who are the infamous writers and directors of such low-brow comedic disasters most of the time, laugh-less spoof such as "Date Movie", "Epic Movie", "Meet the Spartans" and the worst of all "Disaster Movie". Although Friedberg and Seltzer wrote an slightly more coherent script. The best thing about "Vampires Suck" is Jenn Proske as Becca, she captures Kristen Stewart performance as Bella from the "Twilight" movies. Proske is dead on in the movie. Bader is well-cast as her dad. Anneliese van der Pol is amusing as Jennifer, she makes fun of Anna Kendrick's role as Jessica quite well.
